excerpt: “Decision Making: What Makes a Decision Good,” was the topic of a recent webinar held by the SPE Human Factors Technical Section.
title: Situational Awareness, Cognitive Biases Influence Decision Making

excerpt: Floating LNG (FLNG) units have a higher risk of explosion than onshore plants because of the limited and congested environment on the ship. This paper focuses on proper design to address this hazard.
title: Challenges in a Multidisciplinary Approach for Explosion Design for Floating Facilities

excerpt: Improving safety culture is an important goal that can improve, and eventually eliminate HSE incidents in oil and gas.
title: Collaboration, Openness are Critical to Success of Zero-Incident HSE Culture

excerpt: This paper presents a technique that results in an occupied structure being located properly and constructed to reduce the risk of harm to the occupants to a tolerable level.
title: Risk-Based Analysis and Engineering of Safe Distances Between Occupied Structures and Processing Equipment

excerpt: Companies have developed a greater understanding of the causes and effects of long-term fatigue on workers by adapting risk-based approaches to fatigue management. But it is important to incorporate work-site causes of fatigue.
title: Work-site Assessment Required for Effective Fatigue Risk Management

excerpt: SPE's report on Worst Case Discharge is designed to help US offshore operators calculate WCD to comply with the BOEM definition.
title: SPE Publishes Technical Report on Worst-Case Discharges

excerpt: This paper reviews the current methodology for assessing pipeline embedment against field data, in which underprediction of pipeline embedment could be critical to design integrity.
title: An Improved Model for the Prediction of Pipeline Embedment on the Basis of Assessment of Field Data

excerpt: In this article, a methodology is presented for the formation of a facilities engineering organization in an upstream operating company and others such as engineering contractors.
title: Building a High-Performance Facilities Engineering Organization

excerpt: Hybridization of power systems is known to increase energy efficiency and reduce emissions, with lower fuel consumption. This paper reviews available technologies to serve as a selection guide for planning such systems.
title: A Review of Engineering and Safety Considerations for Hybrid-Power (Lithium-Ion) Systems in Offshore Applications

excerpt: In a recent webinar, the speaker discussed mistakes companies make when prices are falling along with steps to help manage project costs in difficult economic times.
title: Oil Price Downturn Requires a Closer Look at Project Cost

excerpt: Mature fields still have value, and technology can help to capture that value through increased efficiency and reduced costs.
title: Technological Innovation Needed To Extract Value from Mature Fields

excerpt: Project managers for megaprojects that will take years to complete require special skills to deal with the many challenges. As a result, engineering and construction firms report a shortage of project managers.
title: Megaprojects Call for the “Total Project Manager”

excerpt: The SPE Separation Technology Technical Section (STTS) is presenting a webinar titled “Advances in High Capacity Internals and Performance Boosting With Inline Pre-separation”
title: STTS Webinars Focus on Scrubber Designs

excerpt: Operators have announced reduced budgets and delayed deepwater project sanctions. Despite these reductions, the long term outlook is for increased deepwater spending.
title: Despite Imminent Project Delays, Deepwater Spend To Total USD 210 Billion From 2015 to 2019

excerpt: Operators are increasingly sampling local groundwater prior to drilling as a risk management approach to deal with public concerns about hydraulic fracturing and other activities.
title: Driver of Water Sampling: Science or Risk Management?

excerpt: Public perception is one of the most important variables in determining the success of oil and gas operations, and companies must do more to help shape this perception.
title: Public Perception is Vital to Success of Oil and Gas Industry Operations

excerpt: The SPE Gulf Coast Section’s Projects, Facilities, and Construction study group presented sessions during its spring lecture series on experts’ discussions of the processes involved in metering measurements.
title: PFC Lecture Series Covers Meter Selection and Applications

excerpt: SPE Distinguished Lecturer Patrick Hudson discussed the types of safety culture found in organizations and the ways in which companies can improve their handling of noncompliant behaviors by employees.
title: Proper Handling of Noncompliant Behaviors is Essential Toward Promoting Safety Culture

excerpt: A Chevron subsea manager shares his successful approach to developing capabilities in his organization.
title: Building the Skills Needed of a Good Facilities Engineer

excerpt: Betsy Woudenberg examined recent incidents and described how the oil and gas industry can develop the culture needed to combat cyber espionage in her SPE Digital Energy Technical Section presentation.
title: Healthy Cybersecurity Culture Requires Communication and Awareness

excerpt: PFC Technical Director Howard Duhon asked readers about the drivers of project complexity. Here are the results.
title: Composite Results of the Project Complexity Study

excerpt: Reliability analysis helps identify bottlenecks, assess risk, improve availability, and optimize maintenance. The challenge in Arctic regions is the lack of data -- normal climate analogs may not apply.
title: System-Reliability Analysis by Use of Gaussian Fuzzy Fault Tree: Application in Arctic Oil and Gas Facilities

excerpt: The SPE Delta Section will cohost its annual Gulf of Mexico Deepwater Technical Symposium in New Orleans in August. A variety of topics on deepwater exploration and production (E&P) will be presented.
title: SPE Delta Section To Cohost Deepwater Technical Symposium

excerpt: This paper presents data from both pilot tests and field tests of a recent burner retrofit of a horizontal heater treater at an oil sands field in northern Canada.
title: Results of the Field Operation of a Distributed-Flux Burner in a Heater Treater in a Northern Canada Heavy Oil Field: Thermal Performance and Firetube Life

excerpt: Flow assurance issues offshore fall into three main categories -- production chemistry (deposition), operational issues (sand, slugging, foaming, emulsions) and integrity (corrosion, erosion)
title: Technological Advances Needed To Combat Flow Assurance Issues

excerpt: The floating production, storage, and offloading (FPSO) facility Espirito Santo, located offshore Brazil in the Parque das Conchas (BC-10) field, is the world’s first turret-moored FPSO facility to use steel risers for fluid transfer.
title: Espirito Santo: Design and Operational Experience of the Use of Steel Risers on a Turret-Moored FPSO

excerpt: The Tamar deepwater gas development offshore Israel experienced a short 4-year gap between discovery and startup, but doing so required the tough decisions in handling significant flow assurance issues.
title: Tamar Startup Provides Lessons Learned

excerpt: A recent webinar provides six reasons for ensuring strong HSSE policies are included in a company's ERP system.
title: Accounting for HSSE in an Enterprise Resource Planning System

excerpt: To provide a best practice approach aimed aimed at reducing delivery time and production costs and improving material quality, a joint industry project led by DNV GL resulted in a recommended practice for steel forgings in subsea applications.
title: Forging of Subsea Equipment: Standardization of Specifications Aims To Improve Delivery Time

excerpt: Many oil and gas companies are pursuing fracture-flowback-water and produced-water recycling for subsequent drilling and fracturing operations. Removal of metals is important to success of these processes.
title: Optimizing Metal-Removal Processes for Produced Water With Electrocoagulation

excerpt: In the face of potential long-term revenue reductions and profit losses, the oil and gas industry needs a carefully planned, well thought-out approach to solving the challenges associated with a protracted widespread market downturn. Fortunately, value-added engineering can be part of the solution.
title: Value-Added Engineering: A Solution to a Down Market

excerpt: Water treatment systems in the North Sea differ from those in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico (GOM). This paper provides a detailed understanding of these differences and provides insight into the design of water-treatment systems in general.
title: Produced-Water-Treatment Systems: Comparison of North Sea and Deepwater Gulf of Mexico

excerpt: When energy and healthcare collaborate, innovation is born. Pumps and Pipes, an unprecedented cross-industry collaboration between oil and gas exploration and production (E&P), cardiovascular medicine, aerospace, and academia, has grown into an international forum for transferable ideas and technolo
title: Cross-Industry Collaboration Ramps Up Flow of Ideas

excerpt: SPE Distinguished Lecturer Joseph Frantz, Jr. says stakeholder opinions will shape the future of hydraulic fracturing.
title: Public Support Necessary for Continued Shale Development

excerpt: New technologies, practices, computer modeling, and design may help to improve the methods for the condition assessment and management of life cycle for risers. As area of recent study has addressed methods to improve the prediction of the riser annulus environment.
title: Current Developments in the World of Risers

excerpt: Though the projects that have already been sanctioned will ensure that spending in the FPS sector will remain high over the forecast period, the growth in FPS market is significantly less than expected due to the collapse in oil prices, and installations in 2018 will decline.
title: Floating Production Systems Expenditure To Total USD 81 Billion From 2015 to 2019

excerpt: Gone are the days when missing a few fingers is a badge of honor in the oilpatch. Author, Distinguished Lecturer and Consultant Ken Arnold discusses how far the the industry has come in prioritizing safety, and what more can be done to improve it.
title: Industry Can Do More To Raise Awareness of Operational Safety

excerpt: Many companies are seeking 20% to 50% reductions in project costs. This level of capital cost reduction requires serious rethinking of the strategy for developing and executing projects.
title: A Strategy For Driving Step Change Reductions in Capital Project Cost

excerpt: Though a best practice for sustainable hydraulic fracturing operations, using nonpotable water creates an environment in which microorganisms thrive. If left unchecked, bacteria can affect the environment and the economic viability of the hydraulic fracturing operation.
title: Bacteria: The Real Water Issue of Hydraulic Fracturing

excerpt: Jimmie Riesenberg, senior process adviser and separations lead at Chevron, discussed the finer points of a scrubber design in a presentation held by SPE Separations Technology Technical Section.
title: Effective Scrubber Design Requires Holistic Approach

excerpt: A few months ago while at lunch with a project team, I heard an engineer lament about how much more difficult it is to execute a project now than in years past.
title: Share Your Experiences in Project Design: Study To Identify Drivers of Complexity

excerpt: A lack of sleep and excessive lighting in the workplace can have negative long-term health effects for industrial shift workers.
title: Sleep, Lighting Measurements Quantify Fatigue Risk

excerpt: Market dynamics and costs drive the search for solutions. In California, where water is needed, producers are finding potential for reuse of waste water.
title: Operators Explore Agricultural Options for Reuse of Flowback and Produced Water

excerpt: The presence of slug flow in the riser of the sunken Deepwater Horizon could make a significant difference in financial penalties for BP in the wake of the Macondo incident, an expert said.
title: Modeling of Macondo Slug Flow Indicates Lower Total Discharge of Oil

excerpt: Southwestern Energy plans to be freshwater neutral in its hydraulic fracturing operations by next year, and the company is well on its way to achieving that goal, said the leader of the group responsible for bringing it to fruition.
title: Southwestern Energy Approaches Goal of Freshwater Neutrality

excerpt: The Produced Water Handling and Management Symposium will be held 20–21 May in Galveston, Texas.
title: SPE Produced Water Handling and Management Symposium

excerpt: Where will the next big idea come from? A number of oil and gas giants are looking to the stars. Not literally, but oil companies are convinced that valuable synergies can be gained by working closely with other industries facing similar challenges.
title: Aerospace, E&P, and Medicine Face Similar Challenges: New Trend Looks Beyond Technology Transfer

excerpt: The SPE Separations Technology Technical Section (STTS) will hold a three-webinar series on the theme of gas scrubbing technology this year with the first to be held on 3 March.
title: Separations Technology Technical Section To Hold Webinar on Scrubber Design

excerpt: A simple, practical, and reliable method to detect a gas leak under the conditions of unknown inlet or outlet gas rate, or unknown inlet or outlet pressure, is highly desirable. This paper discusses such a method.
title: A New Method for Leak Detection in Gas Pipelines

excerpt: The SPE Separations Technology Technical Section (STTS) continues its study of gas scrubbing technology with a special session at the 2015 SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition on 28–30 September in Houston.
title: STTS To Hold Special Session on Gas Scrubber Design at ATCE

excerpt: To help the industry understand offshore-facility weight predictability, IPA recently conducted a comprehensive study that sheds new light on facility weight performance and identifies the root causes of weight growth, providing guidelines for improving predictability.
title: Upstream Offshore-Facility Weight-Growth Study

excerpt: Gerald Verbeek contests the theory that fracturing opposition is meme driven.
title: A Different Take on the Fracturing Meme

excerpt: The 2014 SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition (ATCE) in Amsterdam drew people from all over the world, covered global themes, and focused on the triumphs, challenges, and remaining opportunities for the North Sea.
title: ATCE Highlights: Boosting Recovery From Maturing Fields and Decommissioning

excerpt: Compressor stations often consume 3-5% of the gas they are transporting as fuel. How to minimize this fuel consumption in an optimal manner is the subject of this paper.
title: Optimization of Fuel Consumption in Compressor Stations

excerpt: Thermal recovery often causes variations in heavy oil viscosity. Yet viscosity is key to recovery, reserves estimation, and ultimately project success. A correlation for predicting viscosity is presented.
title: Prediction of Heavy-Oil Viscosities With a Simple Correlation Approach

excerpt: Neil Chapman was appointed as the president of ExxonMobil Chemical and elected to serve as the vice president of ExxonMobil, replacing the retiring Stephen Pryor. Chapman joined the company in 1984, working for an Esso Chemical refinery in the United Kingdom. He advanced within the company in a series of engineering, operations, planning, and marketing roles in chemic…
title: Neil Chapman

excerpt: For many projects, asphaltene management plans are a matter of remediation or prevention. In the past decade, models have been developed to predict how asphaltene particles will behave in oil—the conditions under which precipitation and agglomeration occur.
title: Modeling the Behavior of Asphaltenes

excerpt: After 10 years, the world’s first cell spar, Anadarko’s Red Hawk, was decommissioned. It remained the only cell spar fabricated and again made history as the deepest floating production unit ever decommissioned in the GOM.
title: Lessons Learned as World's First Cell Spar Laid to Rest

excerpt: Steel catenary risers (SCRs) on a large-heave-motion vessel are susceptible to compression in the riser touchdown zone (TDZ). In this paper, a finite-element-analysis modeling method is presented to simulate deformation, pipe ovality, and local pipe buckling.
title: Dynamic Plastic Deformation of Deepwater Steel Catenary Risers Under Extreme Cyclic Compressive Loading

excerpt: You have probably heard that the Eskimo language has several dozen words for “snow,” a frequently repeated and well-known idea. It is untrue. A meme is a snippet of culture that is learned by imitation and passed on by imitation or repetition.
title: The Fracturing Meme

excerpt: Oil prices from USD 50/bbl to USD 60/bbl have been sustained for several weeks, and energy-related stocks have fallen significantly below their 52-week highs and 30% below in some cases.
title: Welcome to 2015: Combating the Uncertainty of Low Oil Prices

excerpt: The development and upgrade of mature facilities is ultimately driven by the significant shift in the composition of the arrival fluids, mainly the increasing water cut and solids production.
title: Life Extension of Mature Facilities Through Robust Engineering and Chemistry Solutions

excerpt: Facility operability is a matter of safety and efficiency. Though most facilities are built and operated successfully, problems sometimes arise during the design phase that can lead to costly incidents.
title: Operator Involvement is Key to Facility Operability

excerpt: Polymer flooding in sensitive areas can require the transport of polymer fluids over long distances. Conventional wisdom limits transport distance or degradation occurs. This paper argues that critical velocity, not distance, is the controlling factor.
title: Degradation (or Lack Thereof) and Drag Reduction of HPAM Solutions During Transport in Turbulent Flow in Pipelines

excerpt: The SPE Separations Technology Technical Section (STTS) hosted a special session titled “Unlocking Hidden Production Potential in Existing and Mature Fields” during the recent ATCE.
title: Optimizing Existing Separation Facilities Maximizes Recovery of Oil

excerpt: Developing performance indicators that will provide meaningful comparisons across the wide variation in oil and gas platforms is important, since good indicators can drive optimal operations. But is is also complex.
title: Thermodynamic Performance Indicators for Offshore Oil and Gas Processing: Application to Four North Sea Facilities

excerpt: While decommissioning is not new, the need is accelerating, along with cost and regulatory requirements. A panel at ATCE discussed the challenges in executing decommissioning projects.
title: Escalation in Decommissioning Costs Drives New Approaches

excerpt: A new federal air quality rule from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) could affect how the oil and gas industry handles waste gas emissions.
title: New EPA Regulation Offers Opportunities for Emissions of Waste Gas

excerpt: Rice University has been working on effective models of phase behavior and asphaltene deposition as a path to improved design that can reduce this challenge for operators.
title: Models for Asphaltene Phase Behavior and Deposition Evolve

excerpt: Subsea power demand is growing to support various processing loads, including pumps and compressors. This paper presents a modular direct-current electrical-power system that is designed for use in a subsea field with medium or long step-out distance
title: A Modular Subsea Direct-Current Electrical-Power System

excerpt: A webinar examined reasons why projects fail to meet profit expectations and how success potential can be enhanced.
title: Radical Change Needed To Improve the Efficiency of E&P Projects

excerpt: While there is no one way to prevent all accidents from occurring, organizations can develop an effective safety culture that allows them to learn from their mistakes.
title: Effective Safety Culture Necessary To Understand Accident Causation

excerpt: Growing world demand for natural gas will drive increases in capital expenditures on LNG through 2019.
title: LNG Capital Expenditure To Total USD 259 Billion in the Next 5 Years

excerpt: For Anadarko, the secret of the “design one, build many” approach to offshore production facilities is to control its enthusiasm for change. The company’s experience with eight operated spars shows the benefits gained with this approach.
title: Spar Innovations: Thinking Inside the Box Reaps Savings

excerpt: Recent and upcoming programming for PFC members is discussed.
title: One Year In

excerpt: High H2S and CO2 content in natural gas pose significant challenges to processing equipment. This article explores the challenges of sulfur removal and high pressures in the presence of acid gas.
title: Taking on the Technical Challenges of Sour Gas Processing

excerpt: With events such as the BP Macondo blowout in the US Gulf of Mexico (2010) and the Pemex Ayatsil-C platform accident (June), the safety risks inherent in oil and gas projects are evident.
title: Project Safety is Critical in Construction and Commissioning

excerpt: LLOG Exploration’s Delta House floating production system (FPS) looms large over Kiewit Offshore Services’ fabrication yard in Ingleside, Texas.
title: LLOG’S Delta House Who Dat Writ Large

excerpt: Although the commissioning of a floating production system (FPS) generally takes place between the “mechanical completion” and “first oil” stages, commissioning activities begin long before then.
title: Commissioning: Making the Connection Between Construction and Operations

excerpt: Upstream separation processes remain a hot topic for facilities engineers. Striving to design separators with the optimal sizing for a variety of reservoir conditions, increasing water cuts, and dynamic gas/oil/water production characteristics is critical, but challenging.
title: Case Study: Sand Separation in Surface Facilities for Heavy and Extra Heavy Oil

excerpt: The term “bright skies” generally connotes optimism, except when used to describe the skies at night. Finding a naturally dark sky has become increasing difficult as the global population and development grows.
title: Oilfield Lighting Threatens the Dark Skies of Night

excerpt: With the Bakken production rate surpassing an average of 1 million BOPD, the issue of crude transport by rail and its regulation has moved to the forefront.
title: Bakken Crude Rides the Rails Under Closer Scrutiny

excerpt: A panel of oil and gas industry experts at the Rice Global Engineering and Construction Forum discussed megaprojects and the joint responsibility of owners and contractors to make them better.
title: Industry Panel Discusses Future of Energy and Construction

excerpt: Riser slugging can restrict production and cause problems for downstream equipment. This paper discusses a simplified modeling approach to control of riser slugging.
title: Simplified Dynamic Models for Control of Riser Slugging in Offshore Oil Production

excerpt: Several different factors contributed to the Macondo accident, according to an analysis by the CSB.
title: CSB Report Reveals New Details, Lessons Learned From Macondo Incident

excerpt: Polymer flooding has been used to enhance the production of oil from mature fields in Oman. This article discusses the trial of several approaches to improve the treatment of water produced from these fields.
title: Polymer-Flood Produced-Water-Treatment Trials

excerpt: Gene Kouba was recognized with the Projects, Facilities and Construction award during ATCE.
title: SPE International Awards Recipient for PFC

excerpt: Companies are deploying a variety of technologies to reduce the water needs of hydraulic fracturing. Where are these new facilities with these new technologies, and how will they help operators solve the problem of finding water to use?
title: Unconventional Resources: New Facilities Find Solutions to Limited Water Sources

excerpt: “Change” was the theme of Offshore Northern Seas (ONS) 2014 in Stavanger, Norway, in August. While commemorating the conference’s 40th anniversary, speakers called for changes in “business as usual.”
title: ONS Focuses on Change: Costs and Climate Change Take Center Stage

excerpt: "Smart water" is needed for effective waterflooding in carbonate reservoirs. A novel water-ionic technology, comprising nanofiltration and reverse-osmosis membrane-based processes, was identified for optimization in this study.
title: Optimization Study of a Novel Water-Ionic Technology for Smart-Waterflooding Application in Carbonate Reservoirs

excerpt: In the August Oil and Gas Facilities, I wrote about the inherency of poetry in our work and how it helps define who we are. In this issue, I share a remarkable example of poetry at work in the mind and heart of an engineer and how it resonated with people and helped to change an industry.
title: Poetry at Work: An Engineer’s Passion for Safety Inspires Industry

excerpt: Natural-gas-actuated pneumatic-control equipment has recently become a focus area for regulators trying to reduce the quantity of actual pollutants and greenhouse gases released to the atmosphere.
title: Pneumatic Controllers in Upstream Oil and Gas

excerpt: SPE’s projects, facilities, and construction (PFC) discipline has had a good track record in developing and delivering workshops on topical themes over the last 10 years or so.
title: Gigaprojects: The Stakes are High and Demand Improved Project Performance

excerpt: The high failure rate of projects is well documented. Companies want to find the most efficient ways of managing their investments, and when those investments do not meet their targets, they want to know the reasons.
title: Taking a Closer Look at Why Projects Fail

excerpt: The factors contributing to out-of-control costs and delayed deliveries of projects are many. They range from unrealistic early cost and time estimates and human factors to the effects of geopolitical events.
title: A Vendor’s View on Cost Control in Megaprojects

excerpt: A few weeks ago, I noticed that someone had viewed my LinkedIn profile. We all have had this happen, and often it will be recruiters or business development professionals looking for contacts, or people who wish to remain anonymous for some reason.
title: The Value of Mentoring in Career Development

excerpt: Over the next 5 years Douglas-Westwood (DW) expect USD 122 billion to be spent on global subsea vessel operations—an increase of 64% compared with the previous 5-year period.
title: Increasing Activity, Complexity, and Water Depths To Push Subsea Vessels Operations Cost Higher

excerpt: While storage and logistics are critical elements of the viability of water reuse, if the water chemistry is not fit for gel fracturing formulations, it will not matter how much is stored in centrally located impoundments.
title: A Comparison of Methods for Boron Removal From Flowback and Produced Waters

excerpt: After severe damage in a typhoon, the Huizhou oil field in the South China Sea was back on production in 5.5 months. This paper reviews how this feat was accomplished.
title: Fast Production Recovery of a Typhoon-Damaged Oil Field in the South China Sea

excerpt: A rigorous SHE&S program on the Barzan Onshore Project tracked 211 deliverables on a monthly basis and led to 131 million man-hours worked without a lost-time incident from July 2012 to March 2014.
title: Barzan Onshore-Gas-Facilities Construction: Attaining Excellence Through a Comprehensive SHE&S Management System

excerpt: Used extensively by the food, chemical, and pharmaceutical industries, the mechanical-vapor-recompression (MVR) process is viewed as a reliable method for recovering demineralized water from concentrated brines. This paper reports on performance of an advanced MVR system in north-central Texas.
title: Mechanical Vapor Recompression for the Treatment of Shale-Gas Flowback Water

excerpt: Engineers who design separators often use rules of thumb. While useful, the theoretical guidelines are typically written for downstream separators and are difficult to apply to the changing dynamics of upstream field conditions.
title: Changing Dynamics of Inflow Drive Upstream Separator Design

excerpt: The SPE Gulf Coast Section’s Project, Facilities, and Construction study group is hosting a series of lectures, “What Have We Learned About Host Selection in Deepwater GOM After 20 Years of Being Off the Shelf?
title: PF&C Summer Lecture Series Focuses on Floating Production Systems

excerpt: This paper presents a statistical analysis approach to weather windows of opportunity, which are defined as the time span over which the stringent, multiparametric conditions required by weather-sensitive marine operations (such as heavy lift, topside float over, and pipeline tie in) are met.
title: Analysis of Windows of Opportunity for Weather-Sensitive Operations

excerpt: This article explores the outlook for the global market and gives insight into technology trends and the regions that hold the biggest opportunities for water treatment.
tags: Permian Basin,Bakken shale,Eagle Ford Shale,unconventional resources,shale oil
title: Unconventional Oil and Gas Production Drives Trends in Water Management and Treatment

excerpt: The application of lessons learned in projects is generally a trusted approach to tackling design challenges. However, the design of onshore production systems for unconventional resources does not allow for straightforward crossover from onshore or offshore conventional to unconventional systems.
title: Design of Onshore Production Systems for Unconventional Resources

excerpt: This paper analyzes the various selection methods of integrated template structures (ITSs) for use in the Arctic environment. Operation and installation of subsea modules in the Barents Sea are also analyzed in this paper.
title: Optimization of Integrated Template Structures for Arctic Subsea-Production Systems

excerpt: The value of new technology, and its ROI, is examined. Understanding the value proposition is not a trivial matter. When investing in facilities technologies, we have traditionally looked to invest in those that will reduce Capex or Opex. But what about niche technologies?
title: How Much Would You Spend To Develop a New Technology?

excerpt: You may not think that poetry and engineering have anything in common, but there is something poetic about the right design that elegantly solves a problem. And, there is undeniably something poetic in making the same mistake again.
title: Poetry at Work: The Poetry of Engineering

excerpt: Severe slugging is characterized by large pressure fluctuations at the base of the riser and is accompanied by fluctuations in fluid delivery from the top of the riser. This instability has negative effects on downstream equipment.
title: Study on Severe Slugging in an S-Shaped Riser: Small-Scale Experiments Compared With Simulations

excerpt: Because of extremely high internal and external pressures, unconventional separator designs must be used in ultradeepwater applications. A major operator has qualified a number of subsea technologies covering a wide range of operating conditions and fluid properties that encompass its subsea portfol
title: Design and Performance Testing of a Subsea Compact Separation System for Deepwater Applications

excerpt: The United States shale boom brought the issue of social license to operate (SLO) to the forefront.
title: Case Study: Repsol Shows the Way To Conserve Ecuador’s Amazon

excerpt: During OTC in Houston last month, offshore construction capabilities drew a room-capacity audience to a technical session about advances in deepwater construction techniques and vessels, including pipelaying and heavy lifting.
title: Offshore Construction and Installation Innovations Aim for Deeper Waters

excerpt: Good early production caused an FPSO to reach the design topside limit with only five wells connected. A study was undertaken to determine how bottlenecks could be reduced to allow greater production without compromising process safety.
title: Debottlenecking Existing Offshore Production Facilities To Safely Extend Their Operation Capacities

excerpt: I was an employee of Union Carbide Corp. (UCC), and like other employees, I know exactly where I was when I first heard the news. Analyzing the root cause of this horrible accident provides insight and opportunities to learn from the mistakes that led to Bhopal.
title: Bhopal: A Root Cause Analysis of the Deadliest Industrial Accident in History

excerpt: Human error is identified as a root cause of accidents and incidents in 60% to 80% of the cases and a causal factor in another 50% to 60% of all mishaps across many industries.
title: Improving Human Performance: Tackling the Challenges To Develop Effective Safety Cultures

excerpt: Roughly one-half of global gas reserves are considered stranded gas--uneconomical because of the remote location of potential markets, lack of economic transportation and infrastructure, or the lack of conversion technology. An FPSO with gas to liquids conversion is an option for stranded gas.
title: GTL FPSO—An Alternative Solution to Offshore Stranded Gas

excerpt: Who are facilities engineers and what is it that they do? The author discusses how the answer to this question has changed during his career in the oil and gas business.
title: Cross-Functional Knowledge: Critical for Today’s Facilities Engineers

excerpt: Flow assurance is a burgeoning field that offers many opportunities to young engineers—provided they are willing to develop expertise in a range of technical disciplines to obtain additional nontechnical skills.
title: Flow Assurance Discipline Offers Career Alternatives

excerpt: Hydraulic fracturing solutions use a gelling agent known as guar gum to transport proppant. Flowback water can have guar gum concentrations has high as 1% by volume creating treatment challenges prior to reuse or disposal.
title: Chemical Pretreatment of Guar Gum-Based Hydraulic Fracturing Solutions and Produced Water

excerpt: The market for floating production systems is growing rapidly, with spending from 2014-2018 expected to increase more than 100% from the prior 5-year period. Factors such as increased local content contribute to growing expenditures.
title: Floating Production Systems Expenditure To Total USD 99 Billion From 2014 to 2018

excerpt: The 2014 Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition (ATCE) will take place in Amsterdam. With its aging wells and processing facilities that present specific challenges, Europe is an interesting place for oil and gas production and applied separations technology.
title: Separations Technology Technical Section Will Hold Special Session at 2014 SPE ATCE

excerpt: This paper reviews the mechanisms of initiation and the prevention of top-of-the-line corrosion (TLC). Recent research and developments are highlighted and validated to arrive at best practices for control of this significant corrosion manifestation.
title: Multifaceted Approaches for Controlling Top-of-the-Line Corrosion in Pipelines

excerpt: Industrial accidents rarely occur because of failures in design. More often, they occur because operators make faulty decisions while under stress or because they do not follow sensible maintenance procedures.
title: Clear, Effective Standard Operating Procedures Needed to Improve Safety

excerpt: Deepwater capital expenditure is expected to more than double compared to the previous 5 year period. Douglas-Westwood also expects a continued trend toward exploration in ultradeepwaters in depths greater than 2000 m.
title: Deepwater Spend Forecast to Surge from 2014 to 2018

excerpt: Wood Group Mustang named John Etherington as general manager of its Malaysia operations in the Asia Pacific region. He is based in Kuala Lumpur and oversees the company’s offshore, onshore, chemicals, oil sands, process plants, industrial, and automation and control markets. Etherington has 26 years of experience in the upstream and downstream sectors of the oil and g…
title: John Etherington-2014

excerpt: Mark Bothamley's series quantifying separation performance in the August-December 2013 issues represents a significant addition to the literature in two-phase separator design. Ken Arnold proposes additional areas of study to take our knowledge even further.
title: Quantifying Separation Performance Taking Bothamley’s Work to the Next Level

excerpt: Human factors may be a trendy term, but human habits are the targets in effecting change in behaviors related to performing work safely. Recent research around what habits are, how they are formed and changed and how they affect our lives has important implications for creating a safety culture.
title: Changing Personal and Organizational Habits to Improve Safety Performance

excerpt: Complexity isn't just about the projects we build, but everything in our work. Everyone is "too busy to help." Can we optimize and free up "engineering hours" to use for more valuable and fun activities?
title: Is Overworking Ourselves Resulting in Ineffectiveness?

excerpt: Modularizing components for facilities sounds like a great idea, but may not be as simple as it seems. The lack of standards is a major impediment. You have to know that parts will work together. But the process of modularization has started and will continue.
title: Lack of Facilities Standards: The Achilles’ Heel of Modularization?

excerpt: LNG will increasingly be the way to bring stranded gas to market so that it can meet demands for clean-burning fuels. LNG basics for engineers was the subject of a recent webinar presentation.
title: Will LNG Plants Meet a Growing Demand for Clean Energy?

excerpt: Project management professionals need to revise the traditional methods of evaluating the efficiency and progress of major projects, if they want to improve their performance record.
title: Project Managers Must Use a More Integrated Approach to Improve Performance

excerpt: The growing attention on sustainable development has prompted many oil and gas companies to take a hard look at their operations and to build a framework for making them more socially responsible.
title: Industry Shows Growing Concern for Sustainable Operations

excerpt: With inconsistent inlet water quality being the rule rather than the exception, sizing and operational considerations of the treatment system components must vary accordingly to make the most economic sense.
title: Optimizing Water Storage in Oilfield Water Treatment

excerpt: As offshore development moves into deeper waters, harsh environments, and longer distances, the economic and practical advantages of moving as many components to the seafloor as possible has become a driving factor in technology development.
title: Seafloor Factory Concept Drives Subsea Power Technology Development

excerpt: Linhua4-1 was China’s first tieback subsea development project. To develop this marginal oil field, a number of technical challenges were overcome through a series of new technologies, and their successful development and implementation.
title: Innovative Solutions Enable Production Start of China’s First Marginal Subsea-Tieback Oil Field

excerpt: Pump Solutions Group (PSG) named three of its executives as presidents of different geographic regions as part of a corporate restructuring program. Ueli Thuerig became president of PSG EMEA (Europe, Middle East, and Africa), Karl Buscher was named president of PSG Americas, and David Wang was appointed president of PSG Asia. Previously, Thuerig was president of PSG E…
title: PSG Changes Corporate Organizational Structure

excerpt: This paper focuses on the applicability of subsea processing technology employing multiphase pumps to develop marginal fields commercially. Analytical methods were used to evaluate the pumps, and the results were validated through case studies in specific fields.
title: Reassessment of Multiphase Pump on Field-Case Studies for Marginal-Deepwater-Field Developments

excerpt: The challenges for operators in the Eagle Ford have been enormous, which can push chemical management to the back burner. But there is a price to be paid down the road. Operators have recently become more mindful of implementing metric-driven chemical management programs.
title: Implementation of a Metric-Driven, Statistical Chemical Management Program for Unconventional Plays

excerpt: This paper describes a series of linear analogs and a solution strategy to improve the accuracy of the Newton-Raphson method for simulating complex natural gas transmission networks.
title: Hybrid Approach by Use of Linear Analogs for Gas-Network Simulation With Multiple Components

excerpt: Could virtual technical communities and modular facilities be the future of oil and gas?
title: Technical Sections for Facilities Engineers and Thoughts on Modular Production Facilities Components

excerpt: The demands for the fresh water used in many hydraulic fracturing operations are placing pressure on water sources in some regions of the United States. Because of the high volumes of water needed for fracturing and competing demands availability of fresh water has decreased and costs have grown.
title: Produced and Flowback Water Recycling and Reuse - Economics, Limitations, and Technology

excerpt: Vibration-induced fatigue failures of pipework smallbore connections result in elevated safety risks and costly interruptions to normal operations. A common cause is poor design. This article discusses design considerations to avoid these failures.
title: Definition of a Cutoff Natural Frequency for Smallbore Pipework Connections

excerpt: Passive fire protection (PFP) has been used as a method to avoid/delay global collapse of offshore installations. Location of PFP is often based on simplistic assumptions, standards, guidance, and methods that do not always consider the real response of the structure to fire.
title: Risk-Based Passive Fire-Protection Optimization

excerpt: Onshore gas developments are often characterized by drilling, fracturing, and production of wells before low-pressure gas-gathering systems are in place. As well production declines, liquid-loading issues begin to appear. Use of a twin-screw pump to boost deliquefication was investigated.
title: Experimental Investigation of Wellhead Twin-Screw Pump for Gas-Well Deliquefication

excerpt: Water condensation and/or hydrate formation at the top of pipelines are serious design/operation considerations in pipelines. This paper reports the results of tests conducted in a new experimental setup constructed for investigating gas-hydrate risks in varied operational scenarios.
title: An Evaluation of Risk of Hydrate Formation at the Top of a Pipeline

excerpt: In this study, a pilot plant with a capacity of 50 m3/d was used to conduct flotation, filtration, and adsorption trials for produced-water treatment at a crude-oil gathering facility.
title: Flotation, Filtration, and Adsorption: Pilot Trials for Oilfield Produced-Water Treatment

excerpt: This paper demonstrates a design methodology that combines the API and American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Boiler and Pressure Vessels Code (BPVC) for designing an example subsea pressure containing component for HP/HT conditions greater than 15,000 psi and 250°F.
title: Design Method Combining API and ASME Codes for Subsea Equipment for HP/HT Conditions up to 25,000-psi Pressure and 400°F Temperature

excerpt: The development of compact topside processing plants for floating, production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessels is a growing industry trend that can reduce operating and capital expenditures over the life of the vessel, a researcher and scientist said recently.
title: Topside Processing Plants Go Compact on FPSOs

excerpt: Reliable separation is becoming an enabling technology to help develop remote location resources and more difficult applications, such as heavy oil, produced water, sand disposal, and back-produced fluids in enhanced oil recovery.
title: Challenges in the Design of Separators

excerpt: A variety of low-cost technologies can result in an increase in production in mature oil and gas fields, although the increase is usually temporary and not always economical.
title: Low-Cost Technologies Can Boost Incremental Production of Mature Fields

excerpt: For this column, I have elected to do a book review on Risk Society by Ulrich Beck in which he argued that we are in the midst of a major cultural change in Western society.
title: Risk Society: The Distribution of “Bads”

excerpt: If you're having trouble figuring out how to get involved with SPE, here's how.
title: Make a Decision Today to Volunteer

excerpt: Much like a character in a novel, a young professional can build their career character.
title: Building Your Career Character

excerpt: A recent webinar focused on hydrocyclones and their application for offshore oil and water separation. The discussion includes fundamental science, practical considerations, implementation and field experience.
title: The Science and Technology of Hydrocyclones

excerpt: This paper discusses novel technologies for increasing the energy efficiency of offshore oil and gas platforms. Three case studies are in progress that are based on actual oil-producing platforms—two on the Norwegian Continental Shelf (NCS) and one in the Brazilian basin.
tags: CO2,CO2 emissions,energy efficiency,emissions,carbon capture and storage
title: Energy-Efficient Technologies for Reduction of Offshore CO2 Emissions

excerpt: Expenditure is forecast to increase more than operational days because of the move toward deeper waters and more complicated offshore field development programs, which demand higher specification, higher cost ROVs.
title: ROV Work-Class Operation Expenditure to Grow by 80%

excerpt: This is the fifth article in a series covering water management in hydraulic fracturing in unconventional resources. The focus of this article is biological control. Additives to improve fracturing conditions can have negative effects on water treatment.
title: Water Management for Hydraulic Fracturing in Unconventional Resources—Part 5

excerpt: The growing amount of heavy crude processed worldwide has created additional separation challenges, leading some operators to turn to alternative technologies. In some cases, electrocoalescence has been an effective tool to separate oil from water.
title: Electrocoalescence: An Alternative Technology for Separating Emulsions

excerpt: As environments become more challenging, the importance and complexity of flow assurance has evolved. To effectively manage flow assurance, oil and gas operators must take a holistic approach, particularly when working in deepwater offshore environments.
title: Flow Assurance -Hydrates and Paraffin Management

excerpt: Change has remained a constant in the E&C industry for decades, but the firms that have thrived are those that remain true to a core set of basic principles.
title: Discipline, Focus, Execution, and Personnel Development Help E&C Firms Thrive

excerpt: T.D. Williamson named Chad C. Fletcher as vice president of Western Hemisphere operations. In his new role, Fletcher is responsible for strategic initiatives and daily business in the region. He has more than 25 years of experience in the energy business, starting as an engineer in the pipeline industry. He later founded a technology firm, Enginuity International, whi…
title: Chad C. Fletcher

excerpt: There are few deepwater-pipeline operators with expertise in pipeline repairs. This paper describes a strategy developed and implemented on deepwater-pipeline intervention, based on a deepwater operational experience built over a decade.
title: Implementing a Deepwater-Pipeline-Management System

excerpt: The global subsea vessels market is expected to reach more than USD 100 billion in the next five years, with demand up by 23%.
title: Subsea Vessel Operations Market Poised for Increase in Demand

excerpt: In this third article of a three-part series, the results of selected gas/liquid separation case studies/sensitivities are presented to show the effects of key separator selection/sizing decision parameters, fluid properties, and operational parameters.
title: Gas/Liquids Separators—Quantifying Separation Performance—Part 3

excerpt: The ubiquitous nature of separations in facilities led to the development of the Separations Technology Technical Section (STTS) in 2011. In it's 3rd year, more activities are planned. Should you be a member?
title: Separations Technology Technical Section Continues Growth into 2014

excerpt: A growing number of alternatives for treating flowback water enable operators to meet the requirements for discharge or reuse of the water in the fracturing fluid, a scientist said recently.
title: Operators See Range of Options for Treating Flowback Water

excerpt: As producers push logistical and technological limits to operate in deeper water and more remote locations, maintaining and repairing offshore structures can present a number of challenges unique to these environments. One of the costliest is corrosion.
title: Advances in Coatings Protection Extend Offshore Facility Life

excerpt: A wide variety of factors have drawn foreign engineering and construction (E&C) firms to North America, and their presence has changed the dynamics of bidding on projects over the past few years, a panel of experts said recently.
title: Overseas E&C Firms Shake Up North American Market

excerpt: A relatively small concentration of a defoamer can have a significant impact on the dynamics of multiphase flow within a pipe, but the effect is generally temporary.
title: Defoamer Improves Flow, But Effect Is Temporary

excerpt: A wide range of corrosive elements and compounds from a variety of crudes has led to a renewed industry focus on corrosion and the effects it has on pipelines and vessels.
title: Corrosion Monitoring and Mitigation Technologies

excerpt: This is the fourth article of a series covering water management in hydraulic fracturing (HF) in unconventional resources. This article discusses the use of mechanical vapor compression (MVC) as a desalination technology.
title: Water Management for Hydraulic Fracturing in Unconventional Resources—Part 4

excerpt: As the world's supply of crude becomes heavier, many of the world’s oil producers will have to think more carefully about heavy crudes and the challenges they pose for processing, storage, and transportation.
title: The Challenges of Processing and Transporting Heavy Crude

excerpt: Unconventional resources are often in good supply, but difficult and expensive to develop. To develop unconventional resources, technologies like hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling are key, and higher oil prices will help.
title: Technology Critical To Developing Unconventional Resources

excerpt: The smart-field concept is deployed through disseminating elements of tools and infrastructure integrated to bring a level of smartness that can improve the performance of an oilfield asset in a sustainable way. How this is accomplished can vary widely depending on the field.
title: Engineering Aspects in the Design and Implementation of Onshore Smart Oil Fields

excerpt: Facilities sand management is tasked with the goal of ensuring sustained hydrocarbon production when particulate solids are present in well fluids, while minimizing the impact of the produced solids on surface equipment. How to do that?
title: Sand Management Methodologies for Sustained Facilities Operations

excerpt: As low as reasonably practicable (ALARP) is common for management of safety risks, but harder to apply to environmental risks. This paper explores the differences and proposes a modified method to support environmental risk analysis.
title: Use of the ALARP Principle for Evaluating Environmental Risks and Impacts of Produced-Water Discharged to Sea

excerpt: Black & Veatch named John E. Murphy to lead its global construction and procurement operations, a division of the company that has grown by 33% since 2011 to more than 2,000 employees. Murphy will work with current division president Hal Smith in a transitional role through the end of the year. Smith, who has been with the company for 45 years, will retire at the end …
title: John E. Murphy

excerpt: The time for the annual selection of SPE’s Distinguished Lecturers (DLs) is coming soon. If you are unfamiliar with the DL program or have not explored it in depth, consider learning more as the selection process for the 2015–2016 lecture season begins on 1 February 2014.
title: Personal Perspectives of Two Distinguished Lecturers: Experience Opportunity and Adventure

excerpt: In this study, software that is capable of modeling fully transient multiphase flow in wellbore and pipeline has been used to characterize the fluid-hammer effects of well shut-in and startup on the coupled subsurface and surface systems.
title: Simulation of Multiphase Fluid-Hammer Effects During Well Startup and Shut-in

excerpt: Once upon a time, oil and gas production facilities were small, simple, similar, and inexpensive. Back in those times, SPE was focused mainly on the reservoir. Things have changed dramatically. There has never been a better time to be a facilities engineer.

excerpt: The challenges in achieving effective communication between facilities and reservoir engineers were addressed during a dinner and panel session held during the SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition in October.

excerpt: The 2013 SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition (ATCE) in October was a good meeting for facilities engineers: It offered good technical papers, an entertaining dinner panel session, and excellent networking opportunities.
title: Successful PFC Initiatives Lead to Further Growth Planned for 2014

excerpt: This paper illustrates a numerical approach to estimate the deposition profile of precipitated wax crystals and its effect on flow-related parameters in pipelines. Options for avoiding these issues are also explored.
title: Improved Paraffin-Deposition-Profile Estimation in Hydrocarbon Pipelines and Effective Mitigation Review

excerpt: Conversion of very large crude carriers to FPSO's can speed time to first oil under the right conditions, there are many considerations in the planning and execution of these conversions.
title: Tanker Conversions to FPSO Design and Integrity Management -Challenges

excerpt: Chet Morrison Contractors named Michael Brown as general manager of marine construction. Brown has 35 years of experience in the commercial diving industry. Most recently, he held an 8-year tenure as vice president and general manager at EPIC, the commercial diving business unit of TETRA. Brown is an active member of several industry associations and committees, inclu…
title: Michael Brown

excerpt: This is the time of year new graduates join our companies. There is tremendous talent coming into our industry. Over the years, I have developed a number of “observations/home truths,” which I invariably share as part of the dialogue around careers and opportunities.
title: New People and New Thinking for New Challenges

excerpt: Mario Azar was named CEO of the solutions business unit in the oil and gas division of Siemens’ energy sector. Before the appointment, he was executive vice president of Siemens Energy’s gas turbine power plant solutions in the fossil power generation division with responsibility for the business in North and South America. He started his career at Westinghouse Electr…
title: Mario Azar

excerpt: This is the third article of a series on water management for hydraulic fracturing in unconventional resources. This month, water treatment technologies are introduced, beginning with the removal of suspended solids by coagulation/flocculation and electrocoagulation for recycling flowback fluids.
title: Water Management for Hydraulic Fracturing in Unconventional Resources - Part 3 Water Treatment Technologies: Coagulation/Flocculation and Electrocoagulation

excerpt: UniversalPegasus International (UPI) named Tim Brown as senior vice president of business development. Brown has more than 30 years of experience in the engineering and construction sectors. He comes to UPI from Jacobs Engineering, where he held the position of global vice president of inside sales and marketing. Brown was responsible for downstream, upstream, chemica…
title: Tim Brown
